A simple trick to make LLMs more predictable and deterministic (without fine-tuning)

While making the LLM call:
✔️ Set temperature = 0 → always picks the most likely token
✔️ Keep top_p = 0.01 (or ≤0.1 if you must use it) → reduces token sampling randomness
✔️ Combine both → deterministic, repeatable outputs every time

Why it matters:
✅ Stable outputs (no surprises in downstream pipelines)
✅ Reliable classifications & extractions
✅ Easier caching and debugging

Example config:
response = client[dot]chat[dot]completions[dot]create(
 model="gpt-4o-mini",
 messages=[{"role":"user","content":"Classify: 'Refund not received'"}],
 temperature=0,
 top_p=1.0
)

Run this twice, thrice, or a hundred times → you’ll get the same answer. Perfect for enterprise-grade workflows where predictability > creativity.

postContent:
🚨 AI models think Adidas logo has 3 stripes and that's a scary flaw 🚨

Fascinating new research reveals that Visual Language Models (VLMs) from Google DeepMind, Anthropic, and OpenAI are perfect at recognizing common visuals, but fail miserably when those patterns change aka counterfactuals.

✅ 100% accuracy for common visuals:
Zebra → 4 legs
adidas logo → 3 stripes

❌ 17% accuracy for counterfactuals:
Mutated Zebra → 5 legs
adidas-like logo → 4 stripes

The takeaway?
This means AI isn’t truly seeing; it’s recalling what it “knows” from training data.

This has big implications for marketers:
⚠️ Brand safety: AI-powered brand detection in ads or user-generated content may miss counterfeits, altered logos, or spoofed creative.
⚠️ Creative analysis: Campaign testing tools using VLMs might misinterpret visual elements if they deviate from “standard” patterns.
⚠️ Market research: Visual sentiment or competitor analysis could be skewed as it combines visual reasoning with pattern recognition

As AI becomes embedded in marketing workflows, the next wave of VLM innovation will need to focus less on “what’s familiar” and more on what’s actually there.

The big opportunity: Partner with AI marketing vendors who are actively evaluating and training for counterfactual accuracy.

The New York Times' transition from an ads-first to a subscription-first business model was driven by games. But will ads once again become the growth driver, this time also because of games?

NYT Games has been growing at such an explosive rate that, on a day in mid-October of 2023, the average daily active users in the Times Games app—iOS and Android combined—reached 2,615,333. These users aren't just coming to the NYT app to kill time; this is serious business. The NYT subscription bundle starts at $25 a month and surpassed 10 million subscribers in November, with a goal of 15 million by the end of 2027. “A lot of people are actually buying the bundle through our Games product,” says Alex Hardiman, Chief Product Officer at NYT.

But is subscription the only monetization lever for games? No—ads monetization accounts for 60% of revenue for casual games worldwide. So, what's NYT planning in this regard?

Joy Robins, Global Chief Advertising Officer of NYT, mentioned that The New York Times' puzzles and games were played more than 8 billion times last year, with 10 million daily gamers—more than many primetime television shows attract. This is a habitual, engaged, and high-income audience. New York Times Advertising is launching ads within its newest game, Connections, with launch sponsors like Uber Eats. Internal testing by New York Times Advertising has shown that this new ad placement ensures a non-disruptive user experience and is effective for advertisers (with a 0.60% average CTR from Wordle’s collaboration with DoorDash).

While news publishers have historically excelled at awareness-based ad campaigns on a massive scale, the high-engagement nature of games is proving effective at driving lower-funnel tactics. This is a great case study for SME non-gaming app publishers to consider incorporating ad-monetized casual games into their apps to boost their bottom line.

Did you know? 
The Washington Post has also experimented with games, albeit with mixed results. According to two sources familiar with the matter, the paper even considered buying Wordle but missed the opportunity, which was later seen as a significant loss after the Times acquired it.

Sources: Vanity Fair, AdForum, ADWEEK, Axios
